defectslist.title: dvi2bitmap defects/issues list
defectslist.p: This list contains the current defects/issues list for the dvi2bitmap application. As well as specific deficiencies, these `defects' include items which are merely suggestions or TODOs
These are in no particular order, and some have a higher priority than others.

defect.title: dvi2bitmap crashes/hangs when given non-existent input file
defect.p: Most mysterious. The problem seems to be confined to versions of the program build with gcc. It builds OK using Sun's and Compaq's C++ compilers, and with egcs-2.91.66. Eitan was using gcc 2.8.1 on a Sparc and it dumped core; I tried building with apparently the same compiler on a Sparc (hermes), and it didn't dump core, but it did seem to hang. Poking around with gdb suggests it's hanging somewhere in a library destructor, but this is still a little obscure.

resolution.author: Norman
resolution.p: On further investigation (12-Jun-2000) I found it crashing at a variety of places when invoked with a non-existent file as argument. It seemed to be getting itself confused about thrown exceptions (which is what happens when it can't open an input file), executing bits of code it shouldn't, and understandably, therefore, getting itself in a terrible mess. By making some code a little more paranoid, I've made the problem go away, but this is unsatisfying, as I haven't really explained what was going wrong in the first place. It's quite possible I'm doing something illegitimate with the exceptions, but I'm also wondering if it's not gcc 2.8.1 which is at fault, especially as the code has survived the much fussier examination of the Sun and Compaq compilers.
Thus, this is closed, unless I find that there is some problem that definitely isn't down to the compiler.

defect.title: Spacing at small sizes
defect.p: Spacing in small fonts is wrong. If you write $x^{123}$ or ${\scriptstyle \cos x}$, the `123' and the `cos' are strung out from each other. It also seems to happen with small-caps. At first, I thought this was to do with the drift-checking, described in the DVI standard section 2.6.2, perhaps because maths fonts have several zero fontdimen parameters (see the TeXBook, appendix F) but it persists even when that's turned right off. Also, it's actually wrong with a variety of small fonts, such as cmr7, not in specifically maths fonts. Most puzzling.

resolution.author: Norman
resolution.p: Finally tracked this down to a bit of defensive programming in the definition of PkFont::designSize(), which was returning the correct answer at all times except when it really mattered, during font-reading, when it always returned 10pt.

defect.title: Horizontal spacing wrong when used with magnified fonts
defect.p: When you LaTeX that and run it through dvi2bitmap, the horizontal spacing of the vertical lines in the table is wrong. This only happens if you use the 11pt document class option. It turns out that if you use the 10pt documentclass option (the default) or 12pt, then you get cmr10 or cmr12 respectively, in the DVI file; but if you use 11pt, LaTeX (or rather the font-selection scheme) uses magnified cmr10. In other words, this appears to be yet another font magnification problem! Grrr -- why is this so hard?

This is displayed even more clearly by the following Plain file (thanks to `TenThumbs' at the USNO, noted 2002 July 25):
\font\vlarge = cmr10 scaled\magstep4 \nopagenumbers \vlarge BOLD words indeed \bye
which makes it transparently clear that it is specifically font magnification that's confused. Sigh, again.
